params.text:
Telephone

Understanding on the Phone
Language in Action

• Understand and Identify the Elements of the Call
  • Ask for Clarifications/Reformulation
  • Notify Problems with Reception/Signal
Telephone: Introduction

In today's module, we'll sharpen your listening skills to become a confident listener and communicator on the phone. 

You'll learn how to:

1. Understand and identify key elements of a call: Recognize greetings, introductions, and the purpose of the call.

  2. Ask for clarifications and reformulate: Use polite phrases to ask someone to repeat something or speak slower.

  3. Notify problems with reception or signal: Learn appropriate phrases to inform the other person about connection issues.
Understand and Identify the Elements of the Call
Please click on the information boxes to read about key tips and strategies you can use for managing phone calls:
Pay attention to greetings and introductions:
• Listen for phrases like "Hello, this is..." or "May I speak to...?" to identify the caller and the person they are trying to reach.
Focus on the speaker's purpose:
• Identify keywords and phrases that indicate the reason for the call. For example, "I'm calling to inquire about..." or "The reason for my call is to..."
Pick out important details:
• Pay close attention to names, dates, times, numbers, or addresses mentioned during the conversation.
Listen for numbers carefully:
• Numbers can be tricky over the phone. Repeat them back if unsure (e.g., "Did you say the meeting is on July 15th?").
Don't be afraid to take notes:
• Jot down key points like names, dates, or action items while listening to help you remember them later.
Understand and Identify the Elements of the Call
Please listen to three people talking about managing phone calls and fill in the missing words:
Micah:
Bryan:
Anthony:

params.textField: Understanding phone calls can be *tricky*! Sometimes people speak quickly or there's a bad *connection*. But focusing on greetings, the reason for the call, and important *details* like names and dates helps a lot. Taking notes can also be a lifesaver!

params.textField: I used to *struggle* with phone calls, especially with technical details. Now I find it helpful to repeat things back to make sure I *understood* correctly. For example, saying "So, the deadline for the project is next Friday?" can avoid *misunderstandings* later.

params.textField: Being *clear* and concise on the phone is important, but so is being a good listener! Paying attention to what the other person is saying shows you care and helps avoid *mistakes*. If something isn't clear, don't be afraid to ask for *clarification* politely.

params.taskDescription: Please complete the missing word to create useful telephone sentences:

params.textField:
Sorry, could you repeat the *name* of the person I'm speaking to?
I apologize, but I didn't quite catch the *date* for the meeting.
The reason for my call is to *inquire about* the job opening I saw advertised.
Could you please *speak a bit slower*?
Can you hold for a moment while I *write this down*?
The purpose of the call is to *schedule* a meeting to discuss the project.

metadata.title: Understand and Identify the Elements of the Call Drag the Words

params.text: Ask for Clarifications/Reformulation: Flashcards

dialogs.answer: Use this polite request to ask someone to say something again.

dialogs.text: I apologize, but I didn't quite catch that.
dialogs.answer: Another way to ask someone to repeat something you missed.

dialogs.text: Could you please speak a bit slower?
dialogs.answer: This polite request asks the speaker to slow down their pace of speaking.

dialogs.text: Could you spell that out for me?
dialogs.answer: Use this when you have trouble understanding a name or word.
Use this to check your understanding of what the other person said.

dialogs.text: So, if I understand correctly, you're saying...?
dialogs.answer: This phrase rephrases what you heard to confirm your understanding.

params.textField:
So, if I *understand* correctly, you're interested in placing a bulk order for the new product line?
Can I just *confirm* that the meeting is scheduled for Tuesday at 2 pm?
The connection isn't very good, could you please speak a bit *slower*?
Sorry, could you *repeat* the name of the contact person?
The name of the software sounded like "Zenith", could you *spell* that out for me?
I apologize, but I didn't quite *catch* the deadline for the report.

metadata.title: Ask for Clarifications/Reformulation Drag the Words

params.text: Ask for Clarifications/Reformulation: Listening & Quiz

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Why does Bryan call customer service?
answers:
To inquire about a recent order that he hasn't received. 

To place a new order. 

To report a problem with the customer service website.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Micah ask Bryan to clarify?
answers:
The name associated with the order.

The date he placed the order. 

The tracking number for the package.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Micah say is likely the reason Bryan hasn't received his package yet?
answers:
No one was home to sign for the package upon delivery.

The package was lost in the mail. 

The delivery address was incorrect.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Micah:
Bryan:
Please listen to the following telephone conversation and answer the questions:
Dialogue Text:

Micah: Hello, this is customer service. How can I help you today?

Bryan: Hi there, I'm calling about my recent order. The tracking information online says it was delivered yesterday, but I haven't received anything yet.

Micah: I understand. Can I get the name on the order for reference?

Bryan: Sure, it's Bryan Lee.

Micah: Thank you. Let me take a look at your order details here. It looks like your package requires a signature upon delivery. Did anyone answer the door yesterday?

Bryan: No, not actually. Maybe that's why I missed it. So, what happens now?

Micah: No worries at most times a delivery attempt notice is left if no one is home. Have you checked your mailbox for a notice?
Notify Problems with Reception/Signal: Flashcards

dialogs.text: I'm afraid I'm having some trouble hearing you. There seems to be a bad connection.
dialogs.answer: Use this phrase to inform the other person about audio difficulties.

dialogs.text: I'm experiencing some static on the line. Can you hear me alright?
dialogs.answer: Another way to describe audio problems and check if the other person is hearing you clearly.

dialogs.text: I apologize, but the signal seems to be cutting in and out. Would you mind if we hold for a moment?
dialogs.answer: If the connection is very weak, you can suggest putting the call on hold briefly.

dialogs.text: It seems like we might have gotten disconnected. Did you hear what I just said?
dialogs.answer: Use this if the call drops unexpectedly and you're unsure if the other person heard you.

metadata.title: Notify Problems with Reception/Signal Dialogue Cards

params.text: Please read through the following flashcards to see useful phrases you can use when dealing with reception/signal issues during a phone call:
Notify Problems with Reception/Signal: Quiz
Please answer the following questions to create useful sentences:

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: I'm afraid I'm having some trouble _______ you. There seems to be a bad connection. Could you speak a bit louder?
Question 2 of 4: I'm experiencing some _______ on the line. Can you hear me alright?
Question 3 of 4: I apologize, but the signal seems to be _______ in and out. Would you mind if we hold for a moment?
Question 4 of 4: It seems like we might have gotten _______. Did you hear what I just said about the meeting time?

params.taskDescription: Please complete the missing words to create useful sentences:

params.textField:
I apologize, but the signal seems to be cutting in and *out*. Would you mind if we hold for a *moment* while I try to find a better reception spot?
It *seems* like we might have gotten disconnected. Did you *hear* what I just said about the meeting time?
I'm *experiencing* some static on the line. Can you hear me *alright*?
I'm afraid I'm having some *trouble* hearing you. There seems to be a bad *connection*. Could you speak a bit louder?

metadata.title: Notify Problems with Reception/Signal Drag the Words

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Read each question carefully and choose the BEST answer:

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: When listening to a phone call, it's important to pay attention to:
answers:
Greetings, introductions, and the purpose of the call. 

How long the call lasts. 

​​​​​​Every single detail mentioned, regardless of importance.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: If you miss an important detail like a date or time, you can:
answers:
Politely ask the speaker to repeat it. 

Ignore it and hope it comes up again. 

Write down everything you can remember and guess the rest later.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: When you don't understand something on the phone, it's best to:
answers:
Use polite phrases to ask the speaker to clarify. 

Stay silent and hope you figure it out later.

Pretend you understand and move on, even if you're confused.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: You can use the phrase "Can I just confirm that...?" to:
answers:
Check your understanding of what the other person said.

End the conversation quickly. 

Ask the other person to repeat everything from the beginning.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: If you're having trouble hearing the other person on the phone, you can say:
answers:
"I'm having some trouble hearing you. There seems to be a bad connection."

"This phone call is boring, let's talk later." 

​​​​​​​Ignore the problem and hope it gets better on its own.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: If the call gets disconnected unexpectedly, you can say:
answers:
"It seems like we might have gotten disconnected. Did you hear what I just said?"

​​​​​​​"You seem like a nice person, have a good day!"

​​​​​​Wait for the other person to call you back without saying anything.
